abstract: Foreign investors expect the court’s handling of the case to serve as a barometer for the country’s commitment to transparent, fair business dealings.
snippet: Foreign investors expect the court’s handling of the case to serve as a barometer for the country’s commitment to transparent, fair business dealings.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  The Indian tycoons Mukesh and Anil Ambani  the world’s richest two brothers  are enmeshed in a feud so bitter that India’s top politicians, their mother and even a Hindu god have been called upon to broker peace. And all have failed.

headline.main: India’s Top Court to Try to Settle Ambani Feud
headline.print_headline: A Brotherly Quarrel Heads to India’s Top Court

abstract: The Wall Street giants that received a financial lifeline from Washington may have no compunction about paying big bonuses to their dealmakers and traders, but their willingness to deliver “thank you” gifts to President Obama is another question altogether.
snippet: The Wall Street giants that received a financial lifeline from Washington may have no compunction about paying big bonuses to their dealmakers and traders, but their willingness to deliver “thank you” gifts to President Obama is another question a...
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street giants that received a financial lifeline from Washington may have no compunction about paying big bonuses to their dealmakers and traders. But their willingness to deliver “thank you” gifts to President Obama and the Democrats is another question altogether, The New York Times’s David D. Kirkpatrick writes.

headline.main: Financial Giants Donating Little to Obama Party

abstract: Despite a strong quarter in which it attracted investors, BlackRock, the giant money manager, has not been totally successful in winning back all the cash that left its riskier products last year and went into low-yielding cash equivalents perceived as safe.
snippet: Despite a strong quarter in which it attracted investors, BlackRock, the giant money manager, has not been totally successful in winning back all the cash that left its riskier products last year and went into low-yielding cash equivalents perceiv...
lead_paragraph: BlackRock’s chief executive, Laurence D. Fink, had a lot to celebrate on Tuesday as his big investment firm reported third-quarter earnings that exceeded analysts’ estimates. The firm’s hedge funds have nearly erased the losses posted during the financial crisis last year and are at or near their high-water marks. Meanwhile, BlackRock’s other alternative investment strategies were able to attract billions of dollars in new capital for its higher-yielding and riskier asset classes.

headline.main: BlackRock Still Striving to Win Back Investors’ Cash
